NATIONAL MONUMENT FUND
(Motion)


    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That this Assembly resolves, in accordance with the provisions of subsection (2) of section 106 of the Income Tax Ordinance (Chapter 166), that notwithstanding the provisions of section 37 of the said Ordinance the assessable income of persons contributing to the National Monument Fund established for the purpose of constructing the National Monument in Kuala Lumpur, shall be reduced by the amount of any such contribution.

    Sir, I think Members are aware that contributions to useful and notable causes can be exempted from income

Column: 484

tax, and every so often motions to this effect are put to the Assembly for their approval. This motion asking that exemption in respect of income tax may be granted to contributions to the National Monument Fund comes at a very apt moment when we have completed our deliberations on such weighty matters as merger, Malaysia and the referendum.

    Sir, this is a perfectly straightforward and simple matter. Where exemptions are asked from the Assembly, it is the general practice for both the Federal Parliament and the Singapore Assembly to agree to the same resolutions. For instance, last year on 7th August, the Federal Parliament by resolution exempted contributions in respect of our National Theatre Fund -

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Hear, hear!

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: - and in agreeing to exemptions for contributions to the National Monument in Kuala Lumpur, we are merely reciprocating the sentiments held in the Federation on matters of national importance.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Assembly resolves, in accordance with the provisions of subsection (2) of section 106 of the Income Tax Ordinance (Chapter 166), that notwithstanding the provisions of section 37 of the said Ordinance the assessable income of persons contributing to the National Monument Fund established for the purpose if constructing the National Monument in Kuala Lumpur, shall be reduced by the amount of any such contribution.

MOTION OF NO CONFIDENCE


    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    *That this House expresses no confidence in the Government.
*The same motion also stood in the name of Mr David Marshall.


Mr Speaker, Sir, I move this motion of no confidence in the Government because the political situation in Singapore has now come to a most critical stage.

Column: 485



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: For the Barisan Sosialis.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): For you.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The future of all Singapore is at stake and we cannot allow a discredited Government that cater only to the selfish interests of a few P.A.P. leaders to mar and destroy the lives of 1.7 million people of Singapore.

    Sir, the last three years of P.A.P. misrule in Singapore -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Sama sama lah!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- will be recorded in history as the tragedy -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Of the Barisan Sosialis.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - of the P.A.P. and Lee Kuan Yew's regime, but unlike the regimes of old, when the last artificial glow of the P.A.P. is gone and forgotten, there may not even be ruins and ashes left behind.

    The Prime Minister: You are going to burn it all up, are you?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Today because of the P.A.P.'s broken promises, because of their dictatorial rule, because of their Fascist abuse of power, because of their play on communal politics, because of their constant invoking of the Communist bogey to threaten and intimidate the peace-loving people of Singapore -

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: He loves peace!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - because of the self-centred arrogance of the Ministers, because of their blatant dishonesty, because of their placing party considerations above the national interests, because of their sell-out of the interests of the people of Singapore -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: By not arresting the Communists!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - and because of their unreasonably and desperately wanting to railroad the so-called merger arrangements that will bring only national

Column: 486

disunity and unhappiness to the people of Singapore, the P.A.P. are no more a respected Government, no more a Government supported by the majority of the people, and no more a Government of the people. It is now a minority Government completely discredited in the eyes of the people, and everyone in Singapore is counting the days when the P.A.P. will finally be no more and gone for ever, never to return.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng): Fat hope!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: For the P.A.P. it is such a short span of life - only three years - and indeed none of us would have foreseen that the life of the P.A.P. would be so short. The future of the people of a country cannot be decided by a Government that does not have the confidence of the people. We cannot allow a Government that works only for the interests of a tiny minority to impose its will on the will of the vast minority. It is a travesty of democracy and of justice and it is our duty to stop it.

    Sir, let us briefly cast our minds back over the last three years. The P.A.P. started on its journey of power and glory most impressively. In the 1959 general elections, the P.A.P. contested all the 51 seats in the Legislative Assembly; 43 of the P.A.P. candidates were returned, some with large winning margins. It was a triumphant victory, and more than half the votes cast were polled for the P.A.P. When the reactionary Lim Yew Hock Government -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Thank you!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - was replaced by the new Lee Kuan Yew Government, there followed a period of rejoicing amongst the people. The people were happy and they thought that at last they had elected a Government that would look after their interests and not the interests of some colonial master. But alas, such is not the case. No one at that time thought that it would be such a short passing phase in the history of Singapore politics. Never in the history of Singapore has there been a political Party in power

Column: 487

that commanded so much .respect and had such great support of the people in 1959. Everybody had the feeling that the P.A.P. was destined to have a brilliant future and that the new political set-up would definitely come to stay and for some considerable time. But see, Sir, how quickly it has changed -

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr G. Kandasamy): Been betrayed!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- see how quickly and how completely the P.A.P. have destroyed themselves. Never in the history of Singapore has any government given so much hope to our people and let them down so very badly, within so short a time.

    The Prime Minister himself had said the P.A.P. could only be destroyed by the P.A.P. deviating from its stand and if the P.A.P. were dishonest. He said that in 1959. Now, those words of his have come true. The P.A.P., by being dishonest and by having deviated from the original stand of the P.A.P. have destroyed the P.A.P. Amen!

    Let us briefly catalogue the milestones, so to speak, of the P.A.P.'s downfall. From the original impressive number of 43 out of a total of 51 seats in this House in 1959, the initial P.A.P. majority of 35-43 against 8 - was first reduced to 29 in 1960. Then came the split in the Party in the middle of 1961, and the majority was soon reduced to the uneasy figure of 1. Now, this uneasy one-man majority has been changed into a precarious and untenable one-woman minority. Sir, can we still have confidence in such a Government? In July 1961, with still a majority in the House, the Prime Minister introduced a motion to seek the confidence of the House. Yet today -

    The Prime Minister: To draw a line separating the traitors!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- with only an untenable minority the P.A.P. want to carry on, and to carry on, they have to rely very heavily on the support of the S.P.A.-U.M.N.O. Alliance, an organisation which the P.A.P. leaders used to despise and to poke fun at with

Column: 488

disparaging remarks. But fearing this support may be taken away from them soon, the Government will adjourn the House sine die in the fond hope that the P.A.P. Government might yet survive a wee bit longer, a hope which the P.A.P. leaders themselves know will not and cannot be fulfilled.

    The Prime Minister said that the P.A.P. would never ally themselves with the so-called anti-Communist forces which, according to the words of the Prime Minister himself, are often cloaked to hide the reactionary elements ranging from colonial vested interests to enemies of democracy. But see what has happened today. He has to rely more and more heavily on these reactionary elements that are enemies of democracy, and he says he is a non-Communist. Sir, even a blind man, I think, can see that the P.A.P. Government are now on their last legs and, under such circumstances, we should probably have seen the formation of some form of coalition government -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: S.P.A. and Barisan?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But there is no coalition government. Neither the U.M.N.O. nor the somersaulting S.P.A. have received their due share of the spoils of government -

    The Prime Minister: You try to entice them?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Perhaps there is no point in trying to have a coalition government. There may be more from the Government Benches who will take courage in time and stand up for the interests of the people, instead of just sticking around and following the tails of their leaders of the bankrupt and discredited P.A.P. Government. Let us hope they have the courage and the guts to do so, because this is their last chance.

    Sir, today the P.A.P. have become the object of hatred and contempt of the people of Singapore. If only the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance, especially these two, should go into the coffee shops, markets and other places of gathering - that is, really going amongst the people -

Column: 489



    Mr Chan Chee Seng: You go to bars and coffee shops?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - instead of just hiding behind air-conditioned Radio P.A.P., they would better be able to sense the intensity of the people's feelings against the P.A.P.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: You are a real scream!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Everywhere we go we hear that the P.A.P. is dirty -

    An hon. Member: Ch'ow!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: They say the P.A.P. is more dirty than the S.P.A. In fact, they say now that the P.A.P. absolutely stinks. Surely, the Special Branch and other MI 5 scouts of theirs should be able to inform the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance of this feeling of hatred and contempt for them and the Government -

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The Barisan.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: In fact, Sir, not only in Singapore and in the Federation, but also in the Borneo territories and other Afro-Asian countries, the common talk is that the Lee Kuan Yew Government has sold Singapore down the river -

    An hon. Member: Singapore River stinks though!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: And what is worse, the P.A.P. Ministers have sold out Singapore on a time schedule -

    The Prime Minister: Oh, I am worried about that.

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): What phase is it now?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, our debate has been guillotined and every act of the Lee Kuan Yew, Government has been timed to the pleasure of the colonialists and the neo-colonialists. [Interruption]

    The Prime Minister: Sir, on a point of information -

    Mr Speaker: Unless the Member will give way.

Column: 490



    The Prime Minister: Sir,

    Mr Speaker: Order. The Prime Minister cannot talk unless the Member gives way and sits down. Is the Member giving way?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: No, Sir.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Scared!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Prime Minister will have ample opportunity to reply -

    The Prime Minister: No, I want only a few minutes.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But let him hear my piece.

    The Prime Minister: You weary my heart. [Laughter]

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Our Prime Minister and the Ministers of the P.A.P. think it is great fun. They think they can hide their great anxiety and fear of the contempt of the people and the anger of the people by laughing it away.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: You laugh.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Let them realise that if they were to go out into the streets of Singapore without their array of bodyguards, we might not see them again -

    The Prime Minister: Are you threatening me now?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I might remind Members of the Government Benches that this is not really a mass meeting. I have not attended a mass meeting, but I understand there is a lot of heckling at a mass meeting. I suggest that this is not a mass meeting and hon. Members should try not to heckle as much as they can.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee rose -

    Mr Speaker: On a point of order?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: On a point of order. The last words of the Member for Queenstown were really a threat. He said that if we were to go into the streets, we would disappear. Is he going to contrive our disappearance, Mr Speaker, by himself?

Column: 491



    Mr Speaker: Do I take it then that the Minister for Finance has been intimidated?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes.

    Mr Speaker: I ask the Member for Queenstown not to intimidate.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I will never be able to intimidate, Sir, If there is any intimidation, it is not from me. I have no arms on me. It is the people outside, who will go for them hammer and tongs and they will never be able to see themselves alive again.

    I was saying, Sir, that now every action of the P.A.P. has been timed to the pleasure of the colonialists, pro-colonialists and neo-colonialists -

    An hon. Member: Who are they?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- so that our Prime Minister can hand Singapore over to the Federation bound hand and foot on time. Let us ask: is the date 31st August, 1962?

    The Prime Minister: You are getting worried?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- that shows, Sir, from what they have been saying, that they are trying to sell Singapore down the river on time -

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: For how much?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- in order to please forces outside Singapore.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Such as?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, the P.A.P. today do not work for the interests of the people in Singapore. No, Sir, they work for the interests of people outside Singapore -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Where? Peking?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - and for that reason, Sir, they have deservedly earned the contempt and hatred of the people of Singapore the contempt of some and the hatred of more of the people of Singapore -

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: You do not like us, do you?

Column: 492



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Member for Bras Basah knew of this widespread hatred and contempt for the P.A.P., but the others all those who are still associated with the Ministers - tailing them around, condoning and conniving at whatever they do, should awaken early from their stuporous slumber -

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): He is using hard words.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- before it is too late. They are words not easily understood by the Minister for Education.

    Sir, immediately following the Party split, and even before, when the few leaders of the P.A.P. were left with an empty shell of an organisation that has leaders but no followers, the triumvirate of the P.A.P., namely, the Prime Minister, -

    An hon. Member: The Minister for Finance.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Minister for Finance -

    An hon. Member: The Deputy Prime Minister?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- and the Minister for Culture. Anyway, Sir, the Minister for Finance is also the Minister for Culture now. So it makes no difference.

    The Prime Minister: He thinks that they are all the same.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: These three started the smear campaign of the Communist bogey. They had hoped by so doing that the public might be deceived as to what was going on.

    The P.A.P. was disintegrating, but the P.A.P. leaders attempted to paint a picture that it was all the work of a handful of Communists and subversives, and if only the P.A.P. could cleanse themselves of these so-called subversives, then all would be well. But what has happened? Only recently another Central Executive Committee Member has crossed the Floor. Is this again the work of Communists, so-called Communists, and subversives?

Column: 493



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Some of the Members on the Government Benches seem to know a lot more.

    An hon. Member: We know more about you!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: And they dare not face the people and tell them on a public platform. They must hide behind Radio P.A.P.

    Sir, in their desperation today, the P.A.P. have labelled everything - any person, any organisation, any movement - that is against the dishonest P.A.P. dictators as Communist, pro-Communist, or Communist-inspired. The unions, because they are against the Prime Minister, the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Culture, are called Communist-led unions, irrespective of whether they are unions of factory workers or of English-speaking office workers. The civic organisations and the Chinese Schools Old Boys' Associations have been similarly labelled, simply because they are against the dictatorial rule of the Fascists in the persons of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance. Now the Singapore University Socialist Club and the Nanyang University Political Science Society which have organised a Gallup poll on the P.A.P. White Paper merger proposals in Tanjong Pagar constituency, are similarly labelled pro-Communist. The political Parties outside the Legislative Assembly - the Lib-Socs, the United Democratic Party, the Party Rakyat all those that protest against the dishonesty, the cheating, and the dictatorship of the P.A.P. are now all pro-Communist or supposed to be made use of by Communist organisations.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sure, that is right.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: All the people who oppose the sell-out merger are Communists. All those who oppose the humbug of this sham referendum are Communists. And today. Sir, I see in the newspapers that the United Nations may be taking up the matter, and I suppose they also are Communists. [Laughter] In fact, everyone who is against the Prime Minister, the Minister

Column: 494

for Finance and the Minister for Culture, is a Communist or a pro-Communist. How ridiculous can one be? Surely they must have a sense of proportion. Is everything just because it is anti-P.A.P., anti-Lee Kuan Yew and Goh, the work of the omnipotent and the omnipresent Communists? No. Sir, it is not the Communists and subversives that have been at work, it is the bad things, the unforgivable things that the P.A.P. Ministers themselves have done, and are doing, that have given rise to such hatred and contempt, it is a demonstration of the people's discontent against the P.A.P. Government. It is the P.A.P. that have destroyed the P.A.P. And I dare say if more Government Backbenchers could pick up courage and defend the rights and interests of the people, more would be crossing the Floor of the House. And we would be able to -

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: Don't dream of it!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh:- see the spectacle and comedy of the S.P.A.-UMNO Alliance also crossing the Floor - but from the Opposition. of course, to join the P.A.P. Ministers opposite. [Interruption]

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Better not. If you go there, you are finished! [Interruption]

    Mr Speaker: Order. There seems to be a combined orchestra again! We have not reached midnight yet. Let us not have any further interjections. Let us carry on with this debate as fast as we can.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: You see, they are already anticipating, Sir, the tragic comedy of the big double cross.

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the Member for Queenstown talks in that vein, then I cannot really blame the Government Benches for interjecting. If he addresses his remarks to the Chair and proceeds with his speech. I think it will be all right.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I beg your pardon, Sir. My last remark was a repartee to what they had earlier on said.

Column: 495



    Sir, the evidence of this loss of confidence in the P.A.P. Government can easily be seen all over Singapore and even in the Federation and the Borneo territories where the name of the P.A.P. is always mentioned together with epithets that are only used in abusive language.

    If you will remember the National Day celebrations of the past three years, Sir. Contrast the 1960 and 196! National Day celebrations with the National Day celebrations this year. The P.A.P., this year, fearing that the loss of support and depletion in their rank and file would allow the P.A.P. contingent to be totally eclipsed by the Barisan Sosialis contingent if the political Parties were allowed to participate as in previous years, imposed all sorts of restrictions on us. Banners and slogans were not allowed, and contingents from the political Parties were restricted to 60 men per Member of the Legislative Assembly. Calculated on this basis, Sir, the Workers' Party would be allowed to have a team of only 60 in the march past: the United People's Party would be allowed to have 60 times 3 = 180: and the Barisan Sosialis would be allowed 60 times 13 -

    An hon. Member: How many is that?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: 780, Sir.

    An hon. Member: He has written it down there!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Of course, it would give the P.A.P. a chance to put up a larger crowd of 26 times 60, which would be 1,560, exactly double ours. But in spite of all this, unfortunately for the P.A.P. they could not put up a show of strength. The P.A.P. tried their utmost, Sir, to put up a show of strength. Work Brigade boys were given double pay to attend. Certain workers were induced to attend by a special allowance of $1.50 per head. All sorts of inducements were also offered. Sir, all these things are known to everybody. Why should they try to hide? In spite of all this, Sir, in spite of their trying to buy people to attend, the P.A.P. could not muster more than a handful, a mere handful of 300. It was no show of strength. It was a pathetic

Column: 496

spectacle of the loss of confidence in the P.A.P. and a clear demonstration of general discontent against the P.A.P. The workers who were scheduled to hold their own National Day celebrations had all sorts of restrictions placed in their way and they were compelled to cancel a meeting to celebrate National Day. It was indeed, Sir, a city divided. And it was this "City Divided" - which was headlined in the Sunday Mail - that had caused the P.A.P. to get into such fits that they had to threaten to stop the circulation of this Sunday paper in Singapore. And now we understand that the editor of that paper has been transferred to another department in order to placate the wrath of the P.A.P. Ministers.

    Consider again, Sir, the May Day rally of the P.A.P.-sponsored unions in the Happy World Stadium and the rally of the independent unions in the Jalan Besar Stadium. It was described in our Plebeian as a battle of rallies. We had a series of pictures to show the people who attended the two rallies. On the one hand, there were 70,000 to 80.000 who braved the heavy rains in order to show their solidarity against the P.A.P. On the other hand, you had this humbug of a rally in the Happy World Stadium which started with about 6,000, but when the time came for the P.A.P. "adviser" to speak, the crowd had dwindled down to only a few hundred.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: You had a Gallup poll taken there?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, all these are undeniable facts and I see that the Ministers dare not even deny what I say. Because these facts can all be proved, Sir, with pictures which tell stories that nobody can deny.

    The Prime Minister: That is right. We already did so yesterday.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Of course, the P.A.P. leaders, knowing full well how unpopular they have become, dare not hold rallies of their own to meet the people. The people used to flock by the thousands to listen to them -

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: They will flock again.

Column: 497



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - not so very long ago. The P.A.P. were invited to a rally in Anson, Sir. They dared not turn up. They were afraid of the people.

    The Prime Minister: Come off it!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: They just dare not. None of them turned up, Sir. They were afraid that they would be booed.

    The Prime Minister: You mean you were scared of their booing us?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Nowadays, Sir, if the P.A.P. Ministers ever think of holding a rally, they will first make sure that they have some sort of entertainment or show on before they step on to the stage, at least hoping that the people might turn up to see the show and incidentally listen to them at the same tune. That was what happened in Malaysia Week. They had to put on a huge show hoping to attract a crowd to listen to the Prime Minister. But in spite of all that, it was a poor effort. The thousands never turned up. They cannot deny it. All this is due. I believe, to a lack of confidence in the Government. Even in the recent University forum, Sir, I understand that lorry loads of Work Brigade boys were transported there as cheer boys for our Prime Minister.

    The Prime Minister: Come off it!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I do not know. He can deny it later on and we will see what he has to say. The Government are very clever at distorting and inventing stories to cover up all their defects. Sir, the Prime Minister himself had said before that if a government were to function properly they must have the masses on their side.
